content.title: Number System
content.content: Computers represent data as numbers. A number system consists of a Unit, Number (digit), and Base/Radix.

content.title: Use of Binary Numbers in Computer Data Representation
content: Computer represents data in two signal states: High voltage (1) and Low voltage (0).
Data from Secondary Storage is sent to Main Memory and then to CPU converted to binary.
Example of Colour Representation: Dark Purple represented as (135, 31, 120) in Decimal -> (100000111, 11111, 1111000) in Binary.

content.title: Conversion of Decimal Numbers to Binary Numbers
content.method: Divide by 2 until remainder is 0. Write remainders from bottom to top.

sections.title: Conversion among Binary, Octal, Hexadecimal and Decimal Numbers

content.title: Converting Binary Numbers to Decimal Numbers
content.method: Multiply each bit by the power of 2 based on its position.

content.title: Converting Octal Numbers to Decimal Numbers
content.method: Multiply each digit by the power of 8.

content.title: Converting Hexadecimal Numbers to Decimal Numbers
content.method: Multiply each digit by the power of 16.

content.title: Converting Binary Numbers to Octal Numbers
content.method: Group into 3 bits from right. Add zeros to left if needed.

content.title: Converting Binary Numbers to Hexadecimal Numbers
Converting Octal numbers to Binary Numbers
content.method: Convert each digit to its 3-bit binary equivalent.

content.title: Converting Octal numbers to Hexadecimal Numbers
content.method: Octal -> Binary -> Group in 4 bits -> Hexadecimal.

content.title: Converting Hexadecimal Numbers to Binary Numbers
content.method: Convert each digit to its 4-bit binary equivalent.

content.title: Converting Hexadecimal Numbers to Octal Numbers
content.method: Hexadecimal -> Binary -> Group in 3 bits -> Octal.

sections.title: Summary
content: Number systems: Binary (Base 2), Octal (Base 8), Decimal (Base 10), Hexadecimal (Base 16).
Units: Bit, Byte, KB, MB, GB, TB.
Coding systems: BCD (4-bit), ASCII (7-bit), EBCDIC (8-bit), Unicode (16-bit).
